importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2015 to 2025 saw a major shift in pediatric allergy prevention strategies, resulting in a 43% reduction in peanut allergy and a 36% reduction in overall food allergies among U.S. children.

keyTakeAways: Early exposure to peanuts reduces the risk of developing a peanut allergy.
The reversal of previous advice—once advising against peanut exposure—has contributed to a significant decline in peanut allergy cases in the U.S.
The 2015 LEAP study found that Israeli children, who were exposed to peanuts early (e.g., through Bamba snacks), had lower peanut allergy rates than British children, who avoided peanuts.
A new study in Pediatrics analyzing over 120,000 children found a 43% reduction in peanut allergy and a 36% reduction in any food allergy prevalence since the 2015 guideline change.
At least 40,000 children have been spared from developing peanut allergies due to updated guidelines.
Peanut allergies are highly persistent, with only about 10% of affected children outgrowing them.
Implementation of new guidelines is hindered by parental fear, especially regarding exposure of siblings or allergic family members.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new study in the journal Pediatrics shows that reversing long-standing advice against early peanut exposure has significantly reduced food allergies in U.S. children. After a landmark 2015 study (LEAP) found that early introduction of peanuts reduced allergy risk—especially in children of similar ancestry but different exposure patterns—health guidelines were updated in 2015 and 2017. These changes led to a 43% reduction in peanut allergy and a 36% drop in overall food allergy prevalence over the past decade. The study analyzed data from over 120,000 children and attributes the success to early allergen introduction, including peanuts, starting as early as 4 to 6 months in high-risk infants. Despite challenges in implementation due to parental fear and lack of real eating habit data, researchers believe the shift in guidance has prevented at least 40,000 children from developing peanut allergies. Experts note that peanut allergies are persistent, with only about 10% of affected children outgrowing them, making early prevention a crucial public health strategy.
title: Reversing peanut advice prevented tens of thousands of allergy cases, researchers say
